fig.label: Figure 1
fig.sd-panel: A Schematic representation of CD45 exon 5 splicing and CTCF binding in B cell lines and primary T cells, as previously characterized.

B Bisulfite sequencing of CD45 exon 5 DNA in cell types that either include or exclude exon 5 from CD45 mRNA, as indicated. Closed versus open circles indicate the locations of methylated or unmethylated CpGs, respectively. A partial sequencing chromatogram from naïve peripheral T cells demonstrates both bisulfite conversion efficiency and the persistence of methylated cytosines within the CTCF binding site.

p.span: Southern blot of genomic DNA double-digested with BsaHI (methyl-sensitive) and BglI (methyl-insensitive) hybridized to a radiolabeled 5' probe. The absence of BsaHI digestion in BL-E5(+) cells confirmed CTCF binding site methylation.

fig.sd-panel: D Methylated DNA immunoprecipitation (MedIP) with antibodies to 5-methylcytosine (5mC) and 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) in BL41 B cells sorted and maintained based on distinct exon 5 inclusion levels. qPCR with primers against the CD45 gene body, as indicated.
E 5hmC MedIP as in D, but with peripheral human CD4+ T cells sorted on the basis of cell-surface expression of exon 5 containing CD45 isoforms.

fig.label: Figure 2
fig.sd-panel: A BL-E5(+) cells were individually transduced with shRNA-directed against TET1 (TET1-sh1 and TET1-sh3), TET2 (TET2-sh4) or control shRNA. Knockdown efficiency was assessed through qRT-PCR relative to expression of the housekeeping gene RPS16.
B 5hmC MedIP and qPCR for CD45 exon 5 DNA relative to input in control-transduced and TET1 or TET2 depleted BL-E5(+) cells.
C qRT-PCR in shTET1, shTET2 and control-transduced BL-E5(+) cells, showing reduced detection of exon 5/6 junctions relative to a constitutive CD45 junction (exon 7/8) in TET-depleted cells.

sd-panel.p: D Cell-surface staining for CD45RA (exon 4-containing isoforms), CD45RB (exon 5-containing isoforms) and total CD45 (pan) in TET1 or TET2 depleted BL-E5(+) cells. RNAi against either TET protein specifically reduced detection of exon-5 containing CD45 isoforms relative to control.

fig.sd-panel: E TET1 and TET2 RNAi in unmethylated BJAB cells. qRT-PCR for knockdown efficiency (top) and cell-surface staining for exon-5 containing CD45 isoforms (CD45RB, bottom) relative to control-transduced cells.

F Large scale depletion of TET1 in BL-E5(+) cells. MedIP (left and center) and CTCF-ChIP (right) followed by qPCR with the indicated CD45 primers in shTET1 (red, throughout) and sh-control (gray, throughout) cells. MedIP showed decreased 5hmC and increased 5mC, whereas CTCF-ChIP indicated reduced binding to CD45 exon 5 in response to TET1 depletion, as compared to control-transduced cells. Rabbit Ig ChIP served as control.

fig.label: Figure 3
fig.sd-panel: A Naïve CD4+ T cells (black bars, throughout) were isolated from peripheral blood and activated in vitro with antibodies against CD3 and CD28 (red bars, throughout).

sd-panel.p: B Phosphorimaging analysis of CD45 RT-PCR products generated with primers extending from the exon 2/3 junction through exon 7 in the presence of dCTP a-32P. Percent exon 5 inclusion was determined as the sum of the exon 5-containing CD45 variants versus the sum of all CD45 variants.

fig.sd-panel: C MedIP with antibodies specific to 5hmC (left) or 5mC (right) followed by qPCR with the indicated CD45 primers in naïve and activated CD4+ T cells.
D CTCF-ChIP in naïve and activated T cells and relative qPCR for CD45 DNA. Rabbit IgG ChIP served as control.
E qRT-PCR for TET family members normalized to the average of RPS16, Bact, and Ubch5b transcripts in naïve and activated CD4+ T cell cDNA.
F TET1 and TET2 Western Blot in nuclear lysates from naïve and activated CD4+ T cells and p84 immunoblot as a loading control.
G TET1-ChIP in naïve and activated T cells and qPCR for CD45 DNA, relative to mouse IgG control ChIP.

fig.label: Figure 4
fig.sd-panel: A Plasmids containing human CD45 (hCD45) genomic DNA from intron 3 through intron 7 with a wildtype (I3-I7) or mutated exon 5 CTCF binding site (I3-I7*CTCF) were methylated with M.SssI and confirmed through BsaHI digest. Methylated and unmethylated minigenes were transfected into CHO cells for stable clone generation.

B 5hmC and 5mC MedIP were performed in stable clones derived from methylated I3-I7 and I3-I7*CTCF minigenes. Results from individual clones are plotted as a percent of total methylation (n=32 clones) as determined through input normalized IP values for 5hmC or 5mC divided by the sum of the values for 5hmC and 5mC. Methylation in the I3-I7 and I3-I7*CTCF clones used for downstream analysis are indicated by the red and blue bars (WT-hmC and Mut-hmC clones), respectively.

C qRT-PCR for relative exon 5 inclusion in methylated I3-I7 and I3-I7*CTCF minigene-derived mRNA. Results are shown for the average of all the I3-I7 and I3-I7*CTCF clones (n=16 clones of each) as well as individually for the WT-hmC and Mut-hmC clones that were selected for downstream analysis. Values represent mean +/- SEM for the pooled data or the mean +/- SD for the individual clones. p= two-tailed Student's t test comparing the I3-I7 to I3-I7*CTCF values.
D qPCR of minigene exon 5 relative to CHO GAPDH for comparison of hCD45 copy number in the WT- and Mut-hmC clones.

E Bisulfite sequencing of hCD45 exon 5 DNA from the WT- and Mut-hmC clones to confirm the persistence of methylation at the intact and mutated CTCF binding site following stable insertion into the CHO genome.

F CTCF-ChIP in the WT- and Mut-hmC clones and qPCR for hCD45 exons, as indicated. ChIP values represent means +/- SD from three independent IP experiments. p= two-tailed Student's t test comparing WT-hmC and Mut-hmC values.

G Pol II-ChIP in the WT- and Mut-hmC clones, and a WT-C CHO clone generated with an unmethylated hCD45 minigene. qPCR for hCD45 DNA as indicated. ChIP values represent means +/- SD from three independent IP experiments. *p=0.013, **p=0.0089, two-tailed Student's t test comparing the Wt-hmC and Mut-hmC values.
H Summary of the WT- and Mut-hmC data illustrating elevated detection of CTCF and pol II at the wildtype minigene exon 5, relative to the mutated CTCF binding site.

fig.label: Figure 5

sd-panel.p: A, B Unmethylated (WT-C) and hydroxymethylated (WT-hmC) I3-I7 clones were transfected with siRNA against Tet1 and Tet2 (siTet1/2) or non-target siRNA (siNT). qRT-PCR (A) and Western Blot (B) confirmed knockdown efficiency relative to CHO GAPDH and the p84 loading control, respectively.

fig.sd-panel: C 5hmC MedIP and qPCR for human CD45 exon 5 in siTet1/2 and siNT WT-C and WT-hmC clones, relative to a minigene region lacking CpGs.
D CTCF-ChIP and qPCR for human CD45 exon 5 in siTet1/2 and siNT WT-C and WT-hmC CHO clones. Rabbit IgG ChIP served as control.

E qRT-PCR with human CD45 primers in siTet1/2 and siNT WT-C and WT-hmC CHO clones. Per each condition, exon level values are normalized to exon 6 and summarized data are presented relative to siNT to distinguish splicing changes from transcriptional variability.

fig.label: Figure 6
fig.sd-panel: B EMSA with purified CTCF and PCR generated CD45 exon 5 probes with a wildtype or mutated CTCF binding site. Cold competition was performed with unlabeled wildtype probe.

C EMSA with purified CTCF and PCR generated 72 base pair probes symmetrically flanking the exon 5 CTCF binding site. Substitution of modified dCTP allowed for variable CTCF binding site methylation. Cold competition was performed with unmethylated wildtype probe.

D EMSA with purified CTCF and PCR generated 72 base pair exon 5 probes generated in the presence of cytosine or 5caC. Cold competition was performed with unmethylated or 5caC-containing wildtype probe, as indicated. Supershift was accomplished with anti-CTCF antibody.

E Quantification of EMSA from D. The volume of free probe and CTCF complexed probe was determined with ImageQuant software (Molecular Diagnostics). Percent shift represents the complex volume divided by the sum of complex plus free probe.

F MedIP with antibody specific to 5caC followed by qPCR with the indicated CD45 primers in naïve and activated CD4+ T cells. Values represent means +/- SD from three independent IP experiments. p= two-tailed Student's t test comparing the indicated values.

fig.label: Figure 7
fig.sd-panel: A Schematic of genome-wide experiments performed on naïve and activated CD4+ T cells.

sd-panel.p: B Volcano plot of MISO results for all annotated skipped exons. ΔAS exons (in red) have Bayes factor > 10 and a ΔPSI absolute value > 0.10. Within the ΔAS exons, negative ΔPSI values indicate activation-excluded exons, whereas positive ΔPSIs reflect activation-included exons. Unchanged alternative exons (AS, not Δ, dark gray) have a Bayes factor < 10 and a ΔPS| absolute value < 0.10.

fig.sd-panel: C Proximity of exons to CTCF. Genomic coordinates corresponding to alternatively spliced (ΔAS, red), unchanged alternative (AS, not Δ, gray), expressed constitutive (black), or all annotated constitutive exons (white) were intersected with empirically defined CTCF binding sites in naïve and activated CD4+ T cells. Exons were queried for CTCF sites that directly overlap or are located within 1.5 kb upstream or downstream, as indicated. p= Fisher's exact test.

D CTCF binding sites (CBS) with overlapping 5hmC in CD4+ T cells were examined for activation-induced changes in 5hmC as determined by MedIP-seq. Results for exon proximal CTCF sites are shown, as are all intragenic CTCF sites and random intragenic bins. Input adjusted changes in methylation > 10% are indicated.

E Exon proximal CTCF binding sites with activation-induced differential 5hmC were assessed for reciprocal changes in 5mC. The percent of sites with differential 5hmC and 5mC were sorted according to the directional change in methylation. The significance of differences between sites adjacent to different exon classes is indicated (p=one-sided Fisher's exact test).

F ΔAS proximal CTCF binding sites with reciprocal 5hmC/5mC were examined for the impact on alternative splicing. Sites with relative increased 5hmC and decreased 5mC (shown in orange) were considered as potential sites of CTCF gain, whereas sites with decreased 5hmC and increased 5mC (shown in blue) were considered as sites of CTCF loss. Exons were sub-categorized based on CTCF location (upstream or downstream) and assessed for directional changes in splicing as either activation-included (stippled boxes) or activation-excluded (solid boxes). Pie charts show the relationship between affected exon splicing categories and reciprocal methylation at upstream or downstream CTCF binding sites as percent of exons (bottom left). Median +/- standard error of ΔPSI values for exons with up- or downstream CTCF and increased or decreased relative 5hmC are plotted (right), mean values are given above.
